thread.title: Unperturbed by global assault
thread.title_full: Unperturbed by global assault | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: Paul Gilder
title: Unperturbed by global assault
text:
AUSTRALIAN investors have batted away a barrage of curveballs, as the International Monetary Fund warns its 2015 global growth forecast has taken a hit.
Facing a stern test following events in Greece, a disruption to US trade and more heavy-handed tactics on Chinese markets, the local bourse dug in to work a dismal morning session into a positive finish yesterday.
The first volley came from Europe, with debt-laden Greece’s plea for a revised three-year rescue plan appearing to drive a wedge between two of its major creditors.
The proposed package of tax and pension reforms — coming ahead of a weekend summit that has been viewed as Greece’s last-chance saloon — put Germany at odds with the International Monetary Fund.
In a formal request, the Greek Government pledged to “immediately implement a set of measures as early as the beginning of next week”, but stopped short of outlining what that meant.
Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras. Picture: AP
The US was an unlikely source of friction due to a three-hour halt in early afternoon trade on the New York Stock Exchange.
NYSE authorities insisted the glitch was down to a “technical issue” rather than a cyber breach but jittery investors still sent the US market down when trading resumed.
Meanwhile, China’s stockmarket soap opera rolled on on Thursday.
 Unperturbed by global assault
